p: Essential oils of plants, including eucalypts, appear to be good candidates as bioherbicides because of their availability and low cost [ 295]. The herbicide cinmethylin ( Figure 16) was developed by Shell Chemical Comp. based on the monoterpene 1,4-cineole (1-methyl-4-(1-methylethyl)-7-oxabicycloheptane) [ 296]. 1,4-Cineole is a structural isomer of 1,8-cineole, but it is less abundant component of plant essential oil [ 297]. Cinmethylin is a 2-benzyl ether substituted analog of 1,4-cineole, where a benzyl ether moiety is added to decrease the volatility of the cineole ring by several orders of magnitude, thereby rendering it more suitable for herbicide use [ 298]. Cinmethylin was commercialized in 1982 under the trade names of Argold and Cinch and is used in the transplanted rice against grass weeds at low application rates of 25 to 100 g a.i./ha [ 299].
